elements.content: A range of symmetric amidinate ligands RAmAr (R is backbone substituent, Ar is N substituent) have been investigated for their ability to stabilize calcium hydride complexes of the type RAmArCaH. It was found that the precursors of the type RAmArCaN­(SiMe3)2 are only stable toward ligand exchange for Ar = DIPP (2,6-diisopropylphenyl). The size of the backbone substituent R determines aggregation and solvation. The following complexes could be obtained: [RAmDIPPCaN­(SiMe3)2]2 (R = Me, p-Tol), RAmDIPPCaN­(SiMe3)2·Et2O (R = Np, tBu), AdAmDIPPCaN­(SiMe3)2·THF, and AdAmDIPPCaN­(SiMe3)2. Reaction of these heteroleptic calcium amide complexes with PhSiH3 gave only for larger backbone substituents (R = tBu, Ad) access to the dimeric calcium hydride complexes (RAmArCaH)2. (N,aryl)-coordination of the amidinate ligand seems crucial for the stability of these complexes, and the aryl···Ca interaction is found to be strong (17 kcal/mol). Addition of polar solvents led to a new type of trimeric calcium hydride complex exemplified by the crystal structures of (tBuAmDIPPCaH)3·2Et2O and (AdAmDIPPCaH)3·2THF. The overall conclusion of this work is that minor changes in sterics (tBu vs Ad) or coordinated solvent (THF vs Et2O) can have large consequences for product formation and stability.

elements.content: Metal hydride complexes are well-known for their wide range of applications in catalysis and reduction chemistry. Although this chemistry has long been a prerogative of transition-metal and late-main-group-metal chemists, early-main-group-metal hydride complexes have received a growing popularity. This current interest is especially for the alkaline-earth-metal hydrides fueled by applications. Calcium hydride complexes are key intermediates in alkene hydrosilylation or hydrogenation catalysis, whereas magnesium hydride complexes can be intermediates in pyridine hydroboration, although this is controversial. Larger magnesium hydride clusters are of particular interest as molecular model systems for the hydrogen storage material MgH2.
elements.clean_text:
Introduction

Metal hydride complexes are well-known for their wide range of applications in catalysis and reduction chemistry. Although this chemistry has long been a prerogative of transition-metal and late-main-group-metal chemists, early-main-group-metal hydride complexes have received a growing popularity. This current interest is especially for the alkaline-earth-metal hydrides fueled by applications. Calcium hydride complexes are key intermediates in alkene hydrosilylation or hydrogenation catalysis, whereas magnesium hydride complexes can be intermediates in pyridine hydroboration, although this is controversial. Larger magnesium hydride clusters are of particular interest as molecular model systems for the hydrogen storage material MgH2.

elements.content: Despite the current interest in group 2 metal hydride complexes, their syntheses and isolation are challenging. They display considerable ionic bond character which translates to weakly bound ligands and ligand exchange. This is the origin of the Schlenk equilibrium (a) established for Grignard reagents already at an early stage by Schlenk. Such ligand scrambling is fatal for the isolation of well-defined LAeH complexes (Ae = alkaline-earth metal). The enormous lattice energies for saline (AeH2)∞ range from 2171 to 3205 kJ/mol and lead to immediate precipitation of AeH2, redirecting the equilibrium to the homoleptic L2Ae complexes. Although lattice energies for (AeH2)∞ increase with decreasing cation size, difficulties in isolating LAeH complexes counterintuitively increase with increasing metal size in the order Be < Mg < Ca < Sr < Ba. Various examples of beryllium hydride complexes were already reported in the middle of the last century. Defined magnesium hydride complexes have been known since 2008, and hitherto at least 20 further crystal structures have been reported. The first structurally established calcium hydride complex dates from 2006, and only since 2012 have two further structural motives been reported. To the best of our knowledge, there is currently no access to strontium and barium hydride complexes and crystal structures of well-defined complexes are hitherto unknown. Problems in preparing “heavy” alkaline-earth-metal hydride complexes arise from their inherently weak metal–ligand bonds. As ionic character and bond lengths increase along the row in the order Be < Mg < Ca < Sr < Ba, bond energies decrease along the same row in the order Be > Mg > Ca > Sr > Ba. Ligand scrambling according to the Schlenk equilibrium is therefore faster and easier for the heavier metals, which explains the difficulties in isolating their hydride complexes.

elements.content: The key to the synthesis of the heavier alkaline-earth metal hydride complexes is the in situ generation of a heteroleptic LAeH complex and control over the Schlenk equilibrium by the spectator ligand L (b). The following requirements are imposed on the ligand: (i) it should encapsulate the metal and be bulky in order to prevent formation of L2Ae, and thus insoluble AeH2, by steric stress and (ii) it should be strongly bound and therefore preferably bi- or multidentate, in order to avoid ligand scrambling. Achieving these goals is increasingly challenging for the larger metals (Ca, Sr, Ba).

Achieving these goals is increasingly challenging for the larger metals (Ca, Sr, Ba).

elements.content: Using the bulky β-diketiminate ligand DIPP-nacnac, Harder and co-workers isolated the first example of a well-defined calcium hydride complex (1; ). Complex 1 was generated in situ by the reaction of (DIPPnacnac)­CaN­(SiMe3)2·THF with PhSiH3. This “silane method”, known from lanthanide chemistry, has now been proven very successful in group 2 chemistry. In 2012 Okuda and co-workers introduced the monoanionic tetradentate macrocyclic amide-triamine ligand Me3TACD– to generate the cationic calcium hydride complex (Me3TACD)3Ca3H2 + (2; ) using the “silane method”. Very recently, a hydride-rich cationic calcium complex of a similar but neutral ligand, Me4TACD, has been reported: (Me4TACD)2Ca2H3 + (3). The latter was generated in situ by hydrogenation of a calcium silanide complex with H2. It is of interest to note that use of multidentate Me3TACD or Me4TACD hitherto always gave cationic calcium hydride complexes. This is likely due to strong, multiple coordination of the aza-crown ligands, causing dissociation of either a hydride ligand (captured by phenylsilane) or a resonance-stabilized Ph3Si– anion. This clearly demonstrates the weakness of Ca–ligand bonds and demonstrates that for isolation of neutral complexes the ligand denticity should not be too high.

elements.content: Given the importance of calcium hydride complexes as intermediates in Ca-catalyzed reactions, there is 10 years after the isolation of the first calcium hydride complex only very little known about this compound class. This holds especially for neutral well-defined calcium hydride complexes, of which only one example has been reported to date. In order to broaden our knowledge of calcium hydride chemistry, we actively follow the goal to extend this series of complexes with new examples based on new ligands. Herein, we report our recent investigations on using amidinate ligands for the stabilization of neutral calcium hydride complexes.

In order to broaden our knowledge of calcium hydride chemistry, we actively follow the goal to extend this series of complexes with new examples based on new ligands. Herein, we report our recent investigations on using amidinate ligands for the stabilization of neutral calcium hydride complexes.

elements.content: The very versatile N,N-bidentate amidinate (or related guanidinate) ligands are widely used in organometallic chemistry. They are easily accessible, can be tuned by variation of backbone and/or N substituents, and, being bidentate, are often used when strongly bound sterically encumbered ligands are needed. In contrast to the β-diketiminates, their bite angle is somewhat smaller due to a decrease of the six- to four-membered metallacycle. Their enormous flexibility in coordination modes, however, easily compensates for this shortcoming (a). The possibility of (N, aryl)-coordination allows for efficient encapsulation of even large metal cations such as K+, Ba2+, Yb2+, and Sm2+. Recent work by the Westerhausen group has shown a similar coordination mode in calcium amidinate chemistry.
elements.clean_text:
Results and Discussion

The very versatile N,N-bidentate amidinate (or related guanidinate) ligands are widely used in organometallic chemistry. They are easily accessible, can be tuned by variation of backbone and/or N substituents, and, being bidentate, are often used when strongly bound sterically encumbered ligands are needed. In contrast to the β-diketiminates, their bite angle is somewhat smaller due to a decrease of the six- to four-membered metallacycle. Their enormous flexibility in coordination modes, however, easily compensates for this shortcoming (a). The possibility of (N, aryl)-coordination allows for efficient encapsulation of even large metal cations such as K+, Ba2+, Yb2+, and Sm2+. Recent work by the Westerhausen group has shown a similar coordination mode in calcium amidinate chemistry.

elements.content: The strategy followed in synthesizing heteroleptic calcium hydride complexes supported by the amidinate ligand is shown in b (the amidinate ligand is abbreviated by RAmAr in which R represents the backbone substituent and Ar the N substituents). The first target is syntheses of a range of heteroleptic RAmArCaN­(SiMe3)2 complexes. In a second step, these will be converted to hydride complexes by the silane route. The influence of substituents R and Ar on the Schlenk equilibrium will be evaluated.

elements.clean_text:
Synthesis and Structures of Heteroleptic Intermediates: RAmArCaN(SiMe3)2 

Using standard methods, two new amidine ligands have been prepared (R = Np, Ar = DIPP and R = Ad, Ar = DIPP) and four ligands were synthesized according to the literature. To map the steric effects of the backbone substituent (R) and the N substituents (Ar) on the stability of the product, we chose substituents of varying sizes as shown in .

elements.content:
Abbreviations: p-Tol = p-tolyl, Np = neopentyl, Ad = 1-adamantyl, Mes = mesityl, DIPP = 2,6-diisopropylphenyl.

Conversion of the amidine ligand RAmArH into RAmArCaN­(SiMe3)2 can be achieved by reacting it with 2 equiv KN­(SiMe3)2 and CaI2 (route A, b). This is the most direct one-pot synthesis developed by Chisholm et al. for the synthesis of the analogue DIPPnacnacCaN­(SiMe3)2·THF complex and has been employed successfully for the syntheses of amidinate calcium amide complexes by the groups of Westerhausen and Cui. We introduce here the direct deprotonation route in which RAmArH is deprotonated by Ca­[N­(SiMe3)2]2·2Et2O (route B). Although most Ca amidinate complexes are prepared in THF, we use the more volatile and less coordinating solvent Et2O. This may allow for removal of coordinated solvent in the final product, as has been shown before in Ca chemistry, and gives the additional possibility of controlling product composition by removal/addition of a Lewis base.

Conversion of the amidine ligand RAmArH into RAmArCaN(SiMe3)2 can be achieved by reacting it with 2 equiv KN(SiMe3)2 and CaI2 (route A, b). This is the most direct one-pot synthesis developed by Chisholm et al. for the synthesis of the analogue DIPPnacnacCaN(SiMe3)2⋅THF complex and has been employed successfully for the syntheses of amidinate calcium amide complexes by the groups of Westerhausen and Cui. We introduce here the direct deprotonation route in which RAmArH is deprotonated by Ca[N(SiMe3)2]2⋅2Et2O (route B). Although most Ca amidinate complexes are prepared in THF, we use the more volatile and less coordinating solvent Et2O. This may allow for removal of coordinated solvent in the final product, as has been shown before in Ca chemistry, and gives the additional possibility of controlling product composition by removal/addition of a Lewis base.

elements.content: We were able to isolate five new heteroleptic calcium amide complexes supported by an amidinate ligand and characterized these by 1H and 13C NMR as well as by X-ray diffraction (vide infra). The use of a DIPP substitituent at N is absolutely essential for the stabilization of complexes of the type RAmArCaN­(SiMe3)2. Attempted synthesis of a heteroleptic species with a Mes at N gave the homoleptic complex (tBuAmMes)2Ca·Et2O, for which a crystal structure was determined (Supporting Information). The size of the backbone substituent R is less critical for stabilization of the heteroleptic calcium amide complexes and can vary between Me and Ad. It has, however, a strong influence on the composition and structure of the calcium amide intermediates. Small substituents (R = Me, p-Tol) gave Et2O-free dimeric products in which the amido groups bridge two Ca2+ ions. Larger substituents (R = Np, tBu) gave monomeric products of the type RAmDIPPCaN­(SiMe3)2·Et2O. The largest backbone substituent (R = Ad) gave an Et2O-free heteroleptic complex in which the ligand is bound by (N,aryl)-coordination. With few exceptions, all complexes can be obtained by routes A and B. The complex [MeAmDIPPCaN­(SiMe3)2]2 could only be isolated by the direct deprotonation route B. The one-pot salt metathesis route A gave the ate complex (MeAmDIPP)­[N­(SiMe3)2]2CaK (see the Supporting Information for the crystal structure). Formation of K-containing ate complexes is often a problem of the salt-metathesis route. The complex AdAmDIPPCaN­(SiMe3)2 could only be obtained in good yields by using method B (method A gave poor yields of 5–14%). The direct deprotonation route B is therefore the method of choice.

elements.content: Representative crystal structures of the three types of heteroleptic calcium amide complexes are shown in ; selected geometrical data can be found in . Despite crystallization from Et2O, the complex AdAmDIPPCaN­(SiMe3)2 represents an unusual solvent-free product in the series (a). The (N,aryl)-chelating ligand could be regarded as an amide/imine ligand with a localized negative charge on N2. This is corroborated by a long N1–C (1.348(3) Å) and short N2–C (1.319(2) Å) bond. Saturation of calcium’s coordination sphere is achieved partially by aryl coordination (Ca···C distances range from 2.745(2) to 2.925(2) Å) but also by a SiMe···Ca agostic interaction (Ca···C 2.823(2) Å). This causes the amide ligand to coordinate asymmetrically as shown by the significantly different distances Ca···Si1 3.1396(8) Å/Ca···Si2 3.6075(8) Å and angles Ca–N3–Si1 104.31(9)°/Ca–N3–Si2 130.5(1)°. The structure of solvent-free DIPPnacnacCaN­(SiMe3)2 shows a similar asymmetric coordination of the amide ligand. It is of interest to note that solvent-free AdAmDIPPCaN­(SiMe3)2 can only be obtained by synthesis in Et2O. The reaction in THF gave a product of composition AdAmDIPPCaN­(SiMe3)2·THF, in which the amidinate ligand is (N,N)- instead of (N,aryl)-chelating (see ). This shows that small changes in solvent polarity can have large effects on the structure of the product.

This shows that small changes in solvent polarity can have large effects on the structure of the product.

A small change of the backbone substituent R from Ad to tBu gives a dramatic change in product composition (b). It crystallizes as a monomer with an (N,N)-chelating amidinate ligand and is solvated by an additional Et2O ligand. The geometry of tBuAmDIPPCaN­(SiMe3)2·Et2O is closely related to that of tBuAmDIPPCaN­(SiMe3)2·THF recently reported by Westerhausen and co-workers.

The geometry of tBuAmDIPPCaN(SiMe3)2⋅Et2O is closely related to that of tBuAmDIPPCaN(SiMe3)2⋅THF recently reported by Westerhausen and co-workers.

elements.content: Further decrease of the backbone substituent results again in solvent-free products that crystallize as dimers with bridging amide ligands, as shown for example by the structure of [MeAmDIPPCaN­(SiMe3)2]2 (c). Although this dimer lacks crystallographic symmetry, it is pseudo C 2 symmetric (axis through N3 and N4). The unusual Ca coordination geometry, which is strongly distorted from tetrahedral, is noteworthy. This is due to a twist of the amidinate ligand: the orientation between the planes defined by N1–Ca1–N2 and N3–Ca1–N4 deviates strongly from an expected perpendicular arrangement. Instead, an interplanar angle of 53.69(8)° is found. This is likely caused by repulsion between bulky amidinate and amide ligands.

elements.content: This series of structures nicely demonstrates that DIPP substituents are needed to stabilize heteroleptic complexes and that secondary effects from the backbone substituent R are decisive for product composition. A large backbone substituent pushes the DIPP groups forward, thus creating a bulkier ligand. In the extreme case, ligand coordination switches from (N,N)-chelation to (N,aryl)-chelation. Angles and bond distances for each structure type are given in and support this conclusion. It can be generally observed that N–C–N′ angles decrease with a larger backbone substituent R. The C–N–CAr angles increase with increasing bulk of R. This affects amidinate–Ca coordination: the Ca–N–CAr angles decrease with increasing bulk of R, thus showing the important secondary effect of the backbone substituent. It is not ruled out that also different electronic effects (alkyl vs aryl) may play a role in the stability of these heteroleptic complexes, but the trends seen in N–C–N and C–N–CAr angles led us to believe that steric factors are more important.

The C-N-CAr angles increase with increasing bulk of R. This affects amidinate-Ca coordination: the Ca-N-CAr angles decrease with increasing bulk of R, thus showing the important secondary effect of the backbone substituent. It is not ruled out that also different electronic effects (alkyl vs aryl) may play a role in the stability of these heteroleptic complexes, but the trends seen in N-C-N and C-N-CAr angles led us to believe that steric factors are more important.

elements.content: The five heteroleptic calcium amide complexes in were converted with PhSiH3 in C6D6 at room temperature to calcium hydride complexes. In all cases the conversion could be monitored by production of PhSiH2N­(SiMe3)2. We were, however, not able to isolate defined calcium hydride complexes. Samples became turbid and 1H NMR signals for homoleptic calcium amidinate complexes appeared. When the solvent was changed to hexane and the temperature lowered to −30 °C, isolation of calcium hydride complexes were successful but only for the bulkier ligands with R = tBu, Ad. Complexes tBuAmDIPPCaH and AdAmDIPPCaH could be isolated in crystalline yields of 80% and 69%, respectively.
elements.clean_text:
Synthesis and Structures of Calcium Hydride Complexes: RAmDIPPCaH

The five heteroleptic calcium amide complexes in  were converted with PhSiH3 in C6D6 at room temperature to calcium hydride complexes. In all cases the conversion could be monitored by production of PhSiH2N(SiMe3)2. We were, however, not able to isolate defined calcium hydride complexes. Samples became turbid and 1H NMR signals for homoleptic calcium amidinate complexes appeared. When the solvent was changed to hexane and the temperature lowered to -30 °C, isolation of calcium hydride complexes were successful but only for the bulkier ligands with R = tBu, Ad. Complexes tBuAmDIPPCaH and AdAmDIPPCaH could be isolated in crystalline yields of 80% and 69%, respectively.

elements.content: The crystal structure of tBuAmDIPPCaH shows a dimeric aggregate in which the hydride ligands bridge the Ca2+ ions and the terminal amidinate ligand is bound by (N,aryl)-chelation. Unfortunately, the structure is heavily modulated (see Supporting Information for details). Repeated measurement of different samples (partially crystallized from different solvents) at different temperatures did not solve the modulation problems; however, the composition and even positions of the hydride ligands could be estimated by refinement in a supercell. The structure of (tBuAmDIPPCaH)2 is closely similar to that of the Yb analogue (tBuAmDIPPYbH)2 recently reported by Trifonov and co-workers. Given the close relationship between Ca2+ and Yb2+ chemistry, this is not surprising. Both compounds crystallize in an isomorphous form, but modulation problems have not been reported for (tBuAmDIPPYbH)2. Recently, Jones et al. reported the structure of (tBuAmDIPPMnH)2, which has a similar buildup and unit cell (no modulation was observed). As the structure of tBuAmDIPPCaH is essentially similar to that of AdAmDIPPCaH, which is not modulated, we decided to give only detailed information for the latter.

elements.content: The crystal structure of the centrosymmetric dimer (AdAmDIPPCaH)2 is shown in . The hydride ligands were located in the difference Fourier map and refined isotropically. The Ca–H distances (2.17(2) and 2.19(2) Å) compare well to those in (DIPPnacnacCaH·THF)2: range 2.09(4)–2.21(3) Å and average 2.15(4) Å. They are somewhat shorter than those observed in complexes 2 (average 2.33(9) Å), but the standard deviation in the latter is quite large; Ca–H bond distances for 3 are not reported. The nonbonding Ca···Ca′ distance in 3 (3.3696(6) Å) is significantly shorter than that in (DIPPnacnacCaH·THF)2 (3.524(4) Å). Whereas the Ca–N2 distance of 2.336(2) Å is slightly shorter than that in the monomer AdAmDIPPCaN­(SiMe3)2, the CAr···Ca distances (2.739(2)–2.894(2) Å) compare well. The amide/imine character of the AdAmDIPP ligand is supported by a long C–N2 (1.352(2) Å) and short C–N1 (1.318(2) Å) distance.

elements.content: Crystal structure of (AdAmDIPPCaH)2. The hydride ligands (observed and refined) are shown, but the remaining H atoms have been omitted for clarity.
elements.clean_text: 2  Crystal structure of (AdAmDIPPCaH)2. The hydride ligands (observed and refined) are shown, but the remaining H atoms have been omitted for clarity.

elements.content: The flexibility of the amidinate ligand for metal complexation seems the key to the stability of these new amidinate calcium hydride complexes. Bidentate (N,aryl)···Ca coordination allows for isolation of a solvent-free calcium hydride complex (despite the presence of 1 equiv of Et2O in the synthesis of tBuAmDIPPCaH). Their ability for (N,aryl)···Ca coordination makes these ligands more sterically hindered than the DIPPnacnac ligand: (DIPPnacnacCaH·THF)2 crystallized as a THF adduct.
elements.clean_text: The flexibility of the amidinate ligand for metal complexation seems the key to the stability of these new amidinate calcium hydride complexes. Bidentate (N,aryl)⋅⋅⋅Ca coordination allows for isolation of a solvent-free calcium hydride complex (despite the presence of 1 equiv of Et2O in the synthesis of tBuAmDIPPCaH). Their ability for (N,aryl)⋅⋅⋅Ca coordination makes these ligands more sterically hindered than the DIPPnacnac ligand: (DIPPnacnacCaH⋅THF)2 crystallized as a THF adduct.

elements.content: The η6-aryl···Yb interaction in (tBuAmDIPPYbH)2 has been described as being quite robust. Addition of TMEDA did not lead to cleavage of the aryl···metal bond, and recrystallization from THF gave crystals of unsolvated (tBuAmDIPPYbH)2. In addition, the calcium hydride complexes (tBuAmDIPPCaH)2 and (AdAmDIPPCaH)2 show aryl···metal bonds of significant strength. NMR investigations in C6D6 display two heptets and four doublets for the iPr groups, indicating asymmetric bonding of the amidinate ligands. Aryl···Ca bonding is also supported by the unusually high field shift for the p-H of the coordinated DIPP substituent: triplets at 6.52 and 6.56 ppm have been observed for tBuAmDIPP and AdAmDIPP, respectively. Heating a solution of (tBuAmDIPPCaH)2 in C6D6 gave at 350 K coalescence of the two heptets (CHMe2) into one signal and four doublets (CHMe 2) into two signals (see the ). In addition, the triplet at 6.52 ppm (p-H coordinated DIPP) changed to a very broad signal due to coalescence. The activation energy for fast exchange between the two different sides of the amidinate ligand has been estimated as ΔG ⧧ = 16.8 kcal/mol and supports the relatively strong aryl···Ca bond. We presume exchange takes place through a transition state with a symmetrically (N,N)-chelating amidinate ligand. The slightly higher activation energy for exchange in (AdAmDIPPCaH)2 (ΔG ⧧ = 17.7 kcal/mol) is in line with the slightly bulkier adamantyl backbone substituent. The effect of additional Lewis bases on aryl···Ca bonding has been investigated and is discussed in detail below.

elements.content: The 1H NMR chemical shifts of the hydride ligands in (tBuAmDIPPCaH)2 and (AdAmDIPPCaH)2 at 3.09 and 3.07 ppm, respectively, are significantly upfield in comparison to hydride chemical shifts in the calcium hydride complexes 1 (4.45 ppm), 2 (3.99–4.00 ppm), and 3 (4.72 ppm).

elements.content: Solutions of the dimer (AdAmDIPPCaH)2 in toluene-d 8 are remarkably thermally stable: keeping the solution for 1 week at 110 °C gave less than 10% decomposition. In contrast, prolonged heating of a benzene solution of 1 at 75 °C gave decomposition into (DIPP-nacnac)2Ca and CaH2 with a half-lifetime of ca. 24 h.

In contrast, prolonged heating of a benzene solution of 1 at 75 °C gave decomposition into (DIPP-nacnac)2Ca and CaH2 with a half-lifetime of ca. 24 h.

elements.content: During the course of our investigations it became clear that small changes in the solvent medium or the presence and type of coordinated solvents can have a large impact on the stabilities and structures of amidinate calcium hydride complexes. Apart from the solvent, also the backbone substituent R (tBu or Ad) has a pronounced influence on product formation. Details of our studies are summarized in .
elements.clean_text:
Solvent Effects

During the course of our investigations it became clear that small changes in the solvent medium or the presence and type of coordinated solvents can have a large impact on the stabilities and structures of amidinate calcium hydride complexes. Apart from the solvent, also the backbone substituent R (tBu or Ad) has a pronounced influence on product formation. Details of our studies are summarized in .

elements.clean_text: 5  Effects of Solvent (Medium or Coordinated Ligands) and Backbone Substituent on Product Formation

elements.content: A striking example of the effect of coordinated solvent is shown by the observation that it is impossible to convert literature-known tBuAmDIPPCaN­(SiMe3)2·THF into a calcium hydride complex by reaction with PhSiH3. Instead, only indications for formation of the homoleptic products (tBuAmDIPP)2Ca and CaH2 have been found. In contrast, the same reaction with the etherate tBuAmDIPPCaN­(SiMe3)2·Et2O gave an 80% yield of (tBuAmDIPPCaH)2. We assume Et2O is slightly more weakly bound to Ca and can be more easily replaced by the coordinative aryl group in comparison to THF, thus leading to the dimer (tBuAmDIPPCaH)2.
elements.clean_text: A striking example of the effect of coordinated solvent is shown by the observation that it is impossible to convert literature-known tBuAmDIPPCaN(SiMe3)2⋅THF into a calcium hydride complex by reaction with PhSiH3. Instead, only indications for formation of the homoleptic products (tBuAmDIPP)2Ca and CaH2 have been found. In contrast, the same reaction with the etherate tBuAmDIPPCaN(SiMe3)2⋅Et2O gave an 80% yield of (tBuAmDIPPCaH)2. We assume Et2O is slightly more weakly bound to Ca and can be more easily replaced by the coordinative aryl group in comparison to THF, thus leading to the dimer (tBuAmDIPPCaH)2.

elements.content: The latter product does not dissolve well in Et2O, but keeping a suspension of thin colorless needlelike crystals of (tBuAmDIPPCaH)2 in Et2O at 40 °C led to slow dissolution and concomitant formation of large colorless blocklike crystals. X-ray diffraction analysis showed conversion to a trimeric calcium hydride complex with two coordinated Et2O ligands. The crystal structure of (tBuAmDIPPCaH)3·2Et2O represents a new structural type and is shown in a. It is similar to the manganese hydride complex (tBuAmDIPPMnH)3 recently reported by Jones et al., but due to the larger ionic radius of Ca2+, additional ether ligands are bound. Coordination of Et2O ligands to only two of the Ca2+ ions, however, breaks the symmetry of this trimer and results in deformation of a regular hexagon into a ladder-type structure. The Ca2+ ion that is free from Et2O coordination seems to form an additional Ca···H bond along the diagonal of the six-membered Ca3H3 ring. The Ca3–H1 distance of 3.10(2) Å is much longer than the regular Ca–H bonds, and although it may seem questionable whether this should be accepted as a bonding interaction, there should be significant electrostatic attraction. Selected bond distances and angles are shown in . The regular Ca–H bond distances within the six-membered ring vary strongly from 2.16(3) to 2.32(2) Å. This large variation is due to the unusual bonding situation for H1 that shows a nearly linear Ca1–H1–Ca2 angle of 174(1)°, whereas angles around H2 and H3 are 124(1)°. The Ca–H1 bond distances are longer due to the facts that (i) Ca1 and Ca2 are additionally solvated by Et2O, which results in elongation of bonds in comparison to those to four-coordinate Ca3, and (ii) H1 interacts weakly with Ca3, which makes this hydride three-coordinate whereas H2 and H3 are only two-coordinate. The regular Ca–H bonds have an average length of 2.21(2) Å that compares well with the average Ca–H bond distances in 1 (2.15(4) Å) or in (AdAmDIPPCaH)2 (2.18(2) Å).

Average value of two independent but nearly equal trimers.

Attempts to study this unique trimer by NMR failed. Crystals of (tBuAmDIPPCaH)3·2Et2O are insoluble in C6D6. After heating, however, the compound dissolves in the form of the solvent-free dimer (tBuAmDIPPCaH)2 and free Et2O, as could be shown by the 1H NMR spectrum (see the Supporting Information). On account of poor solubility, the dimer crystallizes again in the form of thin needles which means that the dimer → trimer conversion is reversible. Indeed, also treatment with any other apolar solvent (pentane, hexane, toluene) converted the blocklike crystals of the trimer into needlelike crystals characteristic for the dimeric complex. Attempts to dissolve the trimer in THF-d 8 led to decomposition with major formation of homoleptic species (tBuAmDIPP)2Ca.

elements.content: It is Intriguing that substitution of the backbone substituent R = tBu for Ad again shows different behavior. Whereas conversion of tBuAmDIPPCaN­(SiMe3)2·THF with PhSiH3 in hexane gave only homoleptic products, the precursor AdAmDIPPCaN­(SiMe3)2·THF led to successful isolation of the trimer (AdAmDIPPCaH)3·2THF. This complex has the same composition and structure as (tBuAmDIPPCaH)3·2Et2O (see ). The main difference, however, is the fact that the Ca3H3 ring is more regular: the Ca–H bond distances show less variation (2.12(1)–2.23(1) Å) and the bond across the ring is too long to be noteworthy (4.08(3) Å). The trends in the Ca–H bonds and Ca–H–Ca′ angles, however, are the same but less pronounced as for (tBuAmDIPPCaH)3·2Et2O: the diagonals Ca1···H2, Ca2···H3, and Ca3···H1 measure 4.33(1), 4.37(1), and 4.08(1) Å, respectively.

elements.content: Attempts to prepare (AdAmDIPPCaH)3·2THF by addition of THF to the solvent-free dimer failed, and decomposition in homoleptic species was observed instead. Similarly, attempts to abstract the THF ligand by dissolution/suspension in toluene and evaporation of the solvent failed due to formation of homoleptic products. The instability of this trimer in polar as well as apolar solvents prevents further NMR characterization.

elements.content: Attempts to synthesize the Et2O complex (AdAmDIPPCaH)3·2Et2O by addition of Et2O to the solvent-free dimer failed and only (AdAmDIPPCaH)2 was isolated. This shows the importance and strength of the aryl···Ca coordination, which in this case can compete with ether coordination. Requirements and limitations for such calcium π interactions with aryl substituents have been discussed previously by Westerhausen and co-workers. The experiment also shows that simple exchange of the backbone substituent tBu for the slightly larger Ad strengthens the aryl···Ca coordination and prevents Et2O coordination. It demonstrates how minor steric changes can have large impacts on product formation.

elements.content: A series of heteroleptic RAmDIPPCaN­(SiMe3)2·nEt2O complexes has been prepared and characterized. Bulky DIPP substituents at the amidinate N atoms are necessary to prevent ligand exchange to homoleptic species. The size of the backbone substituent can vary over a wide range but determines solvation and aggregation. With small substituents (R = Me, p-Tol) unsolvated dimers are found. Slightly larger substituents (R = Np, tBu) gave Et2O-solvated monomers. The largest backbone substituent (R = Ad) led to a solvent-free monomer in which the amidinate ligand shows (N,aryl)-coordination.
elements.clean_text:
Conclusions

A series of heteroleptic RAmDIPPCaN(SiMe3)2⋅nEt2O complexes has been prepared and characterized. Bulky DIPP substituents at the amidinate N atoms are necessary to prevent ligand exchange to homoleptic species. The size of the backbone substituent can vary over a wide range but determines solvation and aggregation. With small substituents (R = Me, p-Tol) unsolvated dimers are found. Slightly larger substituents (R = Np, tBu) gave Et2O-solvated monomers. The largest backbone substituent (R = Ad) led to a solvent-free monomer in which the amidinate ligand shows (N,aryl)-coordination.

elements.content: Only the complexes with the largest backbone substituent (R = tBu, Ad) could be converted to calcium hydride complexes by reaction with PhSiH3 and crystallized as dimers (RAmDIPPCaH)2. Success in preventing ligand exchange is, however, strongly dependent on the reaction conditions. Reactions should be run in a very apolar solvent such as hexane (aromatic solvents led to ligand exchange) and the temperature should be kept low (−30 to 0 °C). Once formed and isolated, the dimeric calcium hydride complexes are extremely thermally stable: reflux in toluene for 1 week gave <10% decomposition. The key to successful isolation of these calcium hydride complexes is the (N,aryl)-coordination of the amidinate ligand which also persists in solution. The aryl···Ca coordination was found to be quite strong, and bond energies are dependent on the size of the backbone substituent (tBu, 16.8 kcal/mol; Ad, 17.7 kcal/mol).

elements.content: It was found that successful isolation of amidinate calcium hydride complexes strongly depends on the solvent medium and the coordinated solvent. Whereas reaction of tBuAmDIPPCaN­(SiMe3)2·THF with PhSiH3 led to ligand distribution and formation of (CaH2)∞, use of the precursor tBuAmDIPPCaN­(SiMe3)2·Et2O gave access to (tBuAmDIPPCaH)2. Suspension of the latter dimer in Et2O gave a new type of trimeric calcium hydride complex, (tBuAmDIPPCaH)3·2Et2O. Suspension of (AdAmDIPPCaH)2 in Et2O, however, only gave starting material, which demonstrates how aryl···Ca coordination can compete with Et2O···Ca coordination. Reaction of AdAmDIPPCaN­(SiMe3)2·THF with PhSiH3 gave the similar THF-solvated trimer (AdAmDIPPCaH)3·2THF.

Suspension of the latter dimer in Et2O gave a new type of trimeric calcium hydride complex, (tBuAmDIPPCaH)3⋅2Et2O. Suspension of (AdAmDIPPCaH)2 in Et2O, however, only gave starting material, which demonstrates how aryl⋅⋅⋅Ca coordination can compete with Et2O⋅⋅⋅Ca coordination. Reaction of AdAmDIPPCaN(SiMe3)2⋅THF with PhSiH3 gave the similar THF-solvated trimer (AdAmDIPPCaH)3⋅2THF.

elements.content: The main conclusion of this work is that small details in reaction conditions are crucial for successful isolation of calcium hydride complexes. Minor changes in sterics (tBu vs Ad) or coordinated solvent (THF vs Et2O) can have large consequences for product formation and stability.

elements.content: All experiments were carried out in dry glassware under N2 using standard Schlenk techniques and freshly dried and degassed solvents (all solvents were dried over a column except for THF, which was dried over Na and redistilled). The following compounds were synthesized according to the literature procedure: tBuAmDIPPH, tBuAmMesH, MeAmDIPPH, p-TolAmDIPPH, and tBuAmDIPPCaN­(SiMe3)2·THF. CaI2 was obtained by preparing CaI2·4Et2O according to literature procedures and subsequently removing the solvent under high vacuum at 150 °C for 2 days. Synthesis of the new ligands AdAmDIPPH and NpAmDIPPH is described in the Supporting Information. The following reagents were obtained commercially: PhSiH3 and KN­(SiMe3)2 (Sigma-Aldrich), tert-butylacetyl chloride and 1-adamantanecarboxylic acid chloride (Acros Organics), 2,6-diisopropylaniline (TCI), and 2,4,6-trimethylaniline (ABCR). These were used without further purification. NMR spectra were measured on a Bruker Avance III HD 400 MHz or Bruker Avance III HD 600 MHz spectrometer. Elemental analysis was performed with an Hekatech Eurovector EA3000 analyzer. CH elemental analyses of Ca complexes are generally strongly affected by the very high air sensitivity of the complexes, by partial loss of coordinated or crystal lattice solvent molecules, and particularly by formation of very stable Ca carbide or Ca carbonate products that also with additional oxidizers such as V2O5 do not fully react to CO2. This results in C content values tlower han expected and is well-documented for the heavier alkaline-earth-metal complexes of Ca, Sr, and Ba. IR spectra were measured with a Bruker Alpha/ATR spectrometer installed in a glovebox. All crystal structures have been measured on a SuperNova (Agilent) diffractometer with dual Cu and Mo microfocus sources and an Atlas S2 detector. Crystallographic data (excluding structure factors) have been deposited with the Cambridge Crystallographic Data Centre as supplementary publication nos. CCDC 1484556 ([MeAmDIPPCaN­(SiMe3)2]2), 1484557 ([p-TolAmDIPPCaN­(SiMe3)2]2), 1484558 (NpAmDIPPCaN­(SiMe3)2·Et2O), 1484559 (tBuAmDIPPCaN­(SiMe3)2·Et2O), 1484560 (AdAmDIPPCaN­(SiMe3)2), 1484561 ((AdAmDIPPCaH)2), 1484562 ((tBuAmDIPPCaH)3·2Et2O), 1484563 ((AdAmDIPPCaH)3·2THF), 1484564 ((tBuAmMes)2Ca·Et2O), 1484565 ((MeAmDIPP)­[N­(SiMe3)2]2CaK), and 1492969 (AdAmDIPPCaN­(SiMe3)2·THF). Copies of the data can be obtained free of charge on application to the CCDC, 12 Union Road, Cambridge CB2 1EZ, U.K. (fax, (+44)­1223-336-033; e-mail, deposit@ccdc.cam.ac.uk).

Experimental Section

General Considerations

All experiments were carried out in dry glassware under N2 using standard Schlenk techniques and freshly dried and degassed solvents (all solvents were dried over a column except for THF, which was dried over Na and redistilled). The following compounds were synthesized according to the literature procedure: tBuAmDIPPH, tBuAmMesH, MeAmDIPPH, p-TolAmDIPPH, and tBuAmDIPPCaN(SiMe3)2⋅THF. CaI2 was obtained by preparing CaI2⋅4Et2O according to literature procedures and subsequently removing the solvent under high vacuum at 150 °C for 2 days. Synthesis of the new ligands AdAmDIPPH and NpAmDIPPH is described in the Supporting Information. The following reagents were obtained commercially: PhSiH3 and KN(SiMe3)2 (Sigma-Aldrich), tert-butylacetyl chloride and 1-adamantanecarboxylic acid chloride (Acros Organics), 2,6-diisopropylaniline (TCI), and 2,4,6-trimethylaniline (ABCR). These were used without further purification. NMR spectra were measured on a Bruker Avance III HD 400 MHz or Bruker Avance III HD 600 MHz spectrometer. Elemental analysis was performed with an Hekatech Eurovector EA3000 analyzer. CH elemental analyses of Ca complexes are generally strongly affected by the very high air sensitivity of the complexes, by partial loss of coordinated or crystal lattice solvent molecules, and particularly by formation of very stable Ca carbide or Ca carbonate products that also with additional oxidizers such as V2O5 do not fully react to CO2. This results in C content values tlower han expected and is well-documented for the heavier alkaline-earth-metal complexes of Ca, Sr, and Ba. IR spectra were measured with a Bruker Alpha/ATR spectrometer installed in a glovebox. All crystal structures have been measured on a SuperNova (Agilent) diffractometer with dual Cu and Mo microfocus sources and an Atlas S2 detector. Crystallographic data (excluding structure factors) have been deposited with the Cambridge Crystallographic Data Centre as supplementary publication nos. elements.content: CaI2 (1.50 g, 5.10 mmol) and KN­(SiMe3)2 (2.30 g, 11.53 mmol) were suspended in 50 mL of Et2O and stirred under reflux conditions for 5 days. The solvent was then removed under vacuum, and the product was extracted with 100 mL of hexane. Concentration to one-fifth of the initial volume and cooling to 4 °C resulted in the formation of large colorless blocks which were washed twice with ice-cold pentane (10 mL) and dried under vacuum. Further cooling of the isolated mother liquor to −20 °C afforded a new batch of crystals, which were worked up as already described. Yield of the combined batches: 2.54 g, 98%. 1H NMR (400 MHz, C6D6): δ 0.29 (s, 36H, Me3Si), 0.97 (t, 3 J HH = 7.0 Hz, 12H, Et2O), 3.33 (q, 3 J HH = 7.0 Hz, 8H, Et2O). 13C NMR (101 MHz, C6D6): δ 5.8 (Me3Si), 14.4 (Et2O), 65.3 (Et2O). Anal. Calcd for C20H56N2O2Si4Ca: C, 47.18; H, 11.09; N, 5.50. Found: C, 46.90; H, 11.03; N, 5.31.

elements.content:
The complex can be obtained following two different synthetic procedures, route A and B (see b).

Route A

AdAmDIPPH (300 mg, 0.60 mmol) and KN­(SiMe3)2 (240 mg, 1.20 mmol) were dissolved in 20 mL of Et2O and stirred at room temperature for 1 h. CaI2 (177 mg, 0.60 mmol) was added under N2, and the slurry was stirred at 40 °C under reflux conditions for 3 days. Et2O was removed under vacuum, and the product was extracted with 20 mL of hexane. The hexane phase was collected after centrifugation and concentrated to half of its initial volume. Slow cooling to −20 °C resulted in the precipitation of a white powdery product which was washed with cold pentane (5 mL) and dried under vacuum. Yield: 57 mg, 14%.

Synthesis of AdAmDIPPCaN(SiMe3)2 

The complex can be obtained following two different synthetic procedures, route A and B (see b).

Route A

AdAmDIPPH (300 mg, 0.60 mmol) and KN(SiMe3)2 (240 mg, 1.20 mmol) were dissolved in 20 mL of Et2O and stirred at room temperature for 1 h. CaI2 (177 mg, 0.60 mmol) was added under N2, and the slurry was stirred at 40 °C under reflux conditions for 3 days. Et2O was removed under vacuum, and the product was extracted with 20 mL of hexane. The hexane phase was collected after centrifugation and concentrated to half of its initial volume. Slow cooling to -20 °C resulted in the precipitation of a white powdery product which was washed with cold pentane (5 mL) and dried under vacuum. Yield: 57 mg, 14%.

elements.content: AdAmDIPPH (300 mg, 0.60 mmol) was dissolved in 20 mL of toluene and added slowly and dropwise to Ca­[N­(SiMe3)2]2·2Et2O (337 mg, 0.66 mmol) under N2 through a septum. The clear solution was stirred for 4 days at 100 °C, after which the solvent was removed under vacuum. A 20 mL portion of Et2O was added, and the suspension was stirred for an additional 1 h at room temperature, after which the organic phase was extracted by centrifugation, collected, and concentrated to half of the initial volume. Slow evaporation of Et2O at room temperature for 2 days in a glovebox allowed the isolation of single crystals suitable for the X-ray analysis. Yield: 387 mg, 92%. 1H NMR at room temperature shows the presence of a main species characterized by two septets (CHMe2) and four doublets (CHMe 2) but shows additional septets and doublets for another species that disappear nearly completely at low temperature (−30 °C); see the Supporting Information. The second species may be due to monomer–dimer equilibria. At higher temperature (+80 °C) also one species is observed and coalescence of two septets in one broad signal reveal fast exchange between the two different ligand sides. 1H NMR (400 MHz, toluene-d 8, −30 °C): δ 0.01 (s, 18H, Me3Si), 1.20 (d, 3 J HH = 6.7 Hz, 6H, iPr), 1.23 (d, 3 J HH = 6.6 Hz, 6H, iPr), 1.32 (d, 3 J HH = 6.6 Hz, 6H, iPr), 1.37 (d, 3 J HH = 6.6 Hz, 6H, iPr), 1.66 (d, 3 J HH = 11.6 Hz, 3H, Ad), 1.80 (d, 3 J HH = 11.6 Hz, 3H, Ad), 2.00 (s, 3H, Ad), 2.40 (s, 6H, Ad), 2.99 (hept, 3 J HH = 6.7 Hz, 2H, iPr), 3.40 (hept, 3 J HH = 6.7 Hz, 2H, iPr), 6.87–7.16 (m, 6H, Ar). 1H NMR (400 MHz, toluene-d 8, +80 °C): δ −0.10 (s, 18H, Me3Si), 1.23 (d, 3 J HH = 6.6 Hz, 12H, iPr), 1.31 (d, 3 J HH = 6.6 Hz, 12H, iPr), 1.63 (d, 3 J HH = 10.7 Hz, 3H, Ad), 1.73 (d, 3 J HH = 10.7 Hz, 3H, Ad), 1.91 (s, 3H, Ad), 2.26 (s, 6H, Ad), 3.29 (hept, 3 J HH 6.6, 4H, iPr), 6.97 (s, 6H, Ar). 13C NMR (101 MHz, Tol, −30 °C): δ 5.78 (SiMe 3), 20.40, 21.16, 23.82, 24.28, 25.60, 28.76, 28.84, 29.38, 37.07, 42.04, 45.08, 121.21 (Ar), 122.84 (Ar), 137.04 (Ar), 137.61 (Ar), 139.46 (Ar), 144.56 (ar), 145.63 (Ar), 160.52 (Ar), 170.28 (NCN). elements.content: An NMR tube was charged with needlelike crystals of (tBuAmDIPPCaH)2 (35 mg, 38 μmol) and suspended in Et2O (600 μL) and left at 40 °C for 7 days. After a few hours, large colorless blocks started to appear among the small needle-shaped crystals. After 7 days a batch of uniform block-shaped crystals could be observed. Et2O was removed, and the crystals were washed twice with cold pentane (600 μL at −30 °C each) and then measured. Yield: 37.2 mg, 96%. NMR measurement of the product in THF-d 8 gave immediate decomposition into the homoleptic species (tBuAmDIPP)2Ca and CaH2 (see the Supporting Information). The product is extremely insoluble in aromatic solvents. Heating a sample in C6D6 in order to dissolve the crystals gave conversion to the dimer (tBuAmDIPPCaH)2, free Et2O, and traces of homoleptic (tBuAmDIPP)2Ca (see the Supporting Information). Anal. Calcd for (tBuAmDIPPCaH)3·2Et2O, C95H152Ca3N6O2: C, 74.55; H, 10.01. Found: C, 74.96; H, 9.76. Although the C value is outside the range viewed as establishing analytical purity, it matches better with a product in which one of the Et2O ligands is missing as a consequence of workup (drying under high vacuum). (tBuAmDIPPCaH)3·Et2O C91H142Ca3N6O: C, 75.05; H, 9.83. IR (pure, cm–1): ν̃̃ 2957 (s), 2901 (s), 2868 (s), 2845 (s), 2140 (w), 1474 (s), 1427 (s), 1417 (s), 1398 (s), 1382 (s), 1355 (m), 1306 (m), 1259 (m), 1228 (s), 1185 (s), 1076 (w), 1040 (s), 929 (s), 896 (s), 844 (m), 799 (s), 757 (s), 726 (m), 699 (m), 536 (m).

elements.content: AdAmDIPPCaN­(SiMe3)2·(THF) (35 mg, 45.4 μmol) was dissolved in pentane (1 mL) in an NMR tube, and the solution was cooled to −30 °C. PhSiH3 (6.2 μL, 50 μmol) was added at −30 °C. While the tube was kept in the cooling bath, the temperature was raised slowly to room temperature. A uniform batch of colorless blocklike crystals suitable for X-ray diffraction grew over the time of 1 week. The crystals were separated from the mother liquor and washed twice with cold pentane (500 μL at −30 °C each) to be measured. Yield: 23 mg, 86%. Dissolving the complex in C6D6 gave immediate decomposition into homoleptic species and gave a precipitate of presumably CaH2. Anal. Calcd for (AdAmDIPPCaH)3·2THF, C113H166Ca3N6O2: C, 77.08; H, 9.50. Found: C, 77.50; H, 9.42. The elemental analysis matches better with for a product in which one molecule of THF is lost during workup. (AdAmDIPPCaH)3·THF, C109H158Ca3N6O: C, 77.53; H, 9.43. IR (pure, cm–1): ν̃̃ 3051 (w), 2957 (s), 2902 (s), 2137 (w), 1455 (m), 1429 (s), 1394 (s), 1312 (m), 1252 (m), 1234 (m), 1137 (m), 1109 (w), 1056 (m), 1026 (m), 932 (m), 875 (m), 821 (m), 755 (m), 697 (m), 659 (w), 589 (w).

cln_elements.content:
CaI2 (1.50 g, 5.10 mmol) and KN­(SiMe3)2 (2.30 g, 11.53 mmol) were suspended in 50 mL of Et2O and stirred under reflux conditions for 5 days. The solvent was then removed under vacuum, and the product was extracted with 100 mL of hexane. Concentration to one-fifth of the initial volume and cooling to 4 °C resulted in the formation of large colorless blocks which were washed twice with ice-cold pentane (10 mL) and dried under vacuum. Further cooling of the isolated mother liquor to −20 °C afforded a new batch of crystals, which were worked up as already described. Yield of the combined batches: 2.54 g, 98%. 1H NMR (400 MHz, C6D6): δ 0.29 (s, 36H, Me3Si), 0.97 (t, 3 J HH = 7.0 Hz, 12H, Et2O), 3.33 (q, 3 J HH = 7.0 Hz, 8H, Et2O). 13C NMR (101 MHz, C6D6): δ 5.8 (Me3Si), 14.4 (Et2O), 65.3 (Et2O). Anal. Calcd for C20H56N2O2Si4Ca: C, 47.18; H, 11.09; N, 5.50. Found: C, 46.90; H, 11.03; N, 5.31.

Synthesis of AdAm<sup>DIPP</sup>CaN­(SiMe<sub>3</sub>)<sub>2</sub>

The complex can be obtained following two different synthetic procedures, route A and B (see b).

Route A

AdAmDIPPH (300 mg, 0.60 mmol) and KN­(SiMe3)2 (240 mg, 1.20 mmol) were dissolved in 20 mL of Et2O and stirred at room temperature for 1 h. CaI2 (177 mg, 0.60 mmol) was added under N2, and the slurry was stirred at 40 °C under reflux conditions for 3 days. Et2O was removed under vacuum, and the product was extracted with 20 mL of hexane. The hexane phase was collected after centrifugation and concentrated to half of its initial volume. Slow cooling to −20 °C resulted in the precipitation of a white powdery product which was washed with cold pentane (5 mL) and dried under vacuum. Yield: 57 mg, 14%.

Synthesis of <italic>t</italic>BuAm<sup>DIPP</sup>CaN­(SiMe<sub>3</sub>)<sub>2</sub>·Et<sub>2</sub>ORoute A

tBuAmDIPPH (500 mg, 1.19 mmol) and KN­(SiMe3)2 (474 mg, 2.38 mmol) were dissolved in 20 mL of Et2O and stirred for 1 h at room temperature. Then CaI2 (384 mg, 1.19 mmol) was added under N2, and the resulting slurry was stirred for 1 day at 40 °C under reflux conditions. The solvent was removed under vacuum, and 20 mL of hexane was added to extract the product. The hexane phase was centrifuged, collected, and concentrated to half of the initial volume and then cooled to −20 °C for 12 h. The product was isolated as colorless blocks which were washed with cold pentane (2 mL) and dried under vacuum. Yield: 721 mg, 87%.

Route B

tBuAmDIPPH (500 mg, 1.19 mmol) was dissolved in 20 mL of Et2O and added slowly and dropwise to Ca­[N­(SiMe3)2]2·2Et2O (606 mg, 1.19 mmol) under N2 through a septum. The clear solution was stirred for 1 day at room temperature, and then Et2O was removed under vacuum. A 20 mL portion of hexane was added to extract the product. After centrifugation, the collected mother liquor was concentrated to half of its initial volume and slow cooling to −20 °C gave colorless crystals which were washed with cold pentane (2 mL) and dried under vacuum. Yield: 738 mg, 89%. 1H NMR (600 MHz, benzene-d 6): δ 0.04 (s, 18H, Me3Si), 0.96 (t, 3 J HH = 7.0 Hz, 6H, Et2O), 1.00 (s, br, 9H, tBu), 1.30 (d, 3 J HH = 6.4 Hz, 12H, iPr), 1.37 (d, 3 J HH = 6.4 Hz, 12H, iPr), 3.48 (hept, 4H, iPr), 3.57 (q, 3 J HH = 7.0 Hz, 4H, Et2O), 6.96–7.15 (m, 6H, Ar). 13C NMR (151 MHz, C6D6): δ 5.3 (Me3Si), 14.1 (Et2O), 23.1 (iPr), 26.5 (iPr), 28.8 (iPr), 31.4 (C­(CH3)3), 45.6 (C(CH3)3), 65.0 (Et2O), 122.8 (Ar), 123.5 (Ar), 140.6 (Ar), 146.7 (Ar), 178.2 (NCN). Anal. Calcd for C39H71N3OSi2Ca: C, 67.47; H, 10.31; N, 6.05. Found: C, 67.21; H, 10.28; N, 5.90.

Synthesis of NpAm<sup>DIPP</sup>CaN­(SiMe<sub>3</sub>)<sub>2</sub>·Et<sub>2</sub>ORoute A

NpAmDIPPH (400 mg, 0.92 mmol) and KN­(SiMe3)2 (385 mg, 1.93 mmol) were dissolved in 20 mL of Et2O and stirred at room temperature for 1 h. Then CaI2 (297 mg, 1.01 mmol) was added under N2, and the slurry was stirred at 40 °C under reflux conditions for 1 day. Et2O was removed under vacuum and the product extracted with 20 mL of hexane. After centrifugation of the hexane phase, concentration to a fifth of the initial volume, and cooling to −20 °C, colorless crystals were obtained. The crystals were washed with ice-cold pentane (3 mL) and dried under vacuum. Yield: 617 mg, 94%.

Route B

NpAmDIPPH (400 mg, 0.92 mmol) was dissolved in 20 mL of Et2O and added slowly and dropwise to Ca­[N­(SiMe3)2]2·2Et2O (468 mg, 0.92 mmol) under N2 through a septum. The clear solution was stirred for 1 day at room temperature, after which Et2O was removed under vacuum. A 20 mL portion of hexane was added to extract the product. After centrifugation of the hexane phase, concentration to one-fourth of the initial volume, and slow cooling to −20 °C, large colorless blocks of the product were obtained which were washed with ice-cold pentane (2 mL) and dried under vacuum. Yield: 526 mg, 80%. 1H NMR (400 MHz, C6D6): δ 0.07 (s, 18H, Me3Si), 0.55 (s, 9H, MeNp), 1.02 (t, 3 J HH = 7.0 Hz, 6H; Et2O), 1.26 (d, 3 J HH = 6.7 Hz, 12H, iPr), 1.38 (d, 3 J HH = 6.8 Hz, 12H, iPr), 2.45 (s, 2H, CH2-Np), 3.38 (q, 3 J HH = 6.6 Hz, 4H, Et2O), 3.47 (hept, 3 J HH = 6.8 Hz, 4H, iPr), 6.94–7.15 (m, 6H, Ar). 13C NMR (101 MHz, C6D6): δ 5.6 (Me3Si), 14.9 (Et2O), 23.2 (Me-Np), 26.9 (iPr), 28.6 (iPr), 31.4 (iPr), 31.6 (CH2-Np), 39.6 (Np), 65.7 (Et2O), 123.5 (Ar), 123.8 (Ar), 141.9 (Ar), 145.9 (Ar), 177.00 (NCN). Anal. Calcd for C40H73N3OSi2Ca: C, 67.83; H, 10.39; N, 5.93. Found: C, 67.52; H, 10.42; N, 5.77.

Synthesis of [<italic>p</italic>-TolAm<sup>DIPP</sup>CaN­(SiMe<sub>3</sub>)<sub>2</sub>]<sub>2</sub> Route A

p-TolAmDIPPH (200 mg, 0.44 mmol) and KN­(SiMe3)2 (175 mg, 0.88 mmol) were dissolved in 20 mL of Et2O and stirred at room temperature for 1 h. Then CaI2 (129 mg, 0.44 mmol) was added under N2, and the slurry was stirred at 40 °C under reflux conditions for 1 day. Et2O was removed under vacuum and the product extracted with 20 mL of 9/1 pentane/Et2O mixture. The solution of the raw product was concentrated to one-third of its initial volume and layered with pentane. Slow cooling to −20 °C afforded a microcrystalline product which was washed with cold pentane and dried under vacuum. Suitable crystals for X-ray spectroscopy could be obtained on recrystallizing the product from toluene. Yield: 258 mg, 91%.

Route B

p-TolAmDIPPH (200 mg, 0.44 mmol) was dissolved in 5 mL of Et2O and added slowly and dropwise to Ca­[N­(SiMe3)2]2·2Et2O (224 mg, 0.44 mmol) under N2 through a septum. The clear solution was stirred for 1 day at room temperature, after which Et2O was removed under vacuum. A 10 mL portion of toluene was added to extract the product, and after centrifugation of the hexane phase and further concentration to one-fourth of the initial volume, the solution was slowly cooled to −20 °C. Colorless blocks of the product grew overnight which were washed twice with ice-cold pentane (2 mL) and dried under vacuum. Yield: 195 mg, 68%. 1H NMR (300 MHz, C6D6): δ 0.32 (s, 36H, SiMe3), 1.09 (d, 3 J HH = 6.9 Hz, 24H, iPr), 1.17 (d, 3 J HH = 6.9 Hz, 24H, iPr), 1.66 (s, 6H, Me-Tol), 3.53 (hept, 3 J HH = 6.9 Hz, 8H, iPr), 6.49 (d, 3 J HH = 8.1 Hz, 4H, Tol), 6.91 (d, 3 J HH = 8.1 Hz, 4H, Tol), 6.97–7.10 (m, 12H, Ar). 13C NMR (151 MHz, C6D6): δ 7.00 (SiMe3), 22.50 (CH3-Tol), 25.39 (iPr), 29.08 (iPr), 34.46 (iPr), 123.36 (Ar), 123.67 (Ar), 129.87 (Ar), 130.54 (Ar), 131.37 (Ar), 138.04 (Ar), 141.15 (Ar), 145.11 (Ar), 172.80 (NCN). Anal. Calcd for C38H59CaN3Si2: C, 69.77; H, 9.09; N, 6.42. Found: C, 70.00; H, 9.07; N, 6.06.

Synthesis of [MeAm<sup>DIPP</sup>CaN­(SiMe<sub>3</sub>)<sub>2</sub>]<sub>2</sub> Route A

Route A gave the calcate complex (MeAmDIPP)­[N­(SiMe3)2]2CaK (see the Supporting Information).

Route B

MeAmDIPPH (200 mg, 0.53 mmol) was dissolved in benzene (10 mL) and added very slowly to Ca­[N­(SiMe3)2]2·2Et2O (270 mg, 0.53 mmol) under N2 with fast stirring through a septum. The reaction mixture was kept at room temperature for 2 h, after which the clear solution was concentrated to approximately 1 mL. After slow evaporation of the solvent for 2 days in a glovebox, crystals of the compound could be grown. The crystals were washed three times with cold pentane (300 μL). Crystals suitable for X-ray diffraction were grown from C6D6 (500 μL with 25 mg of the product) in an NMR tube. Yield: 179 mg, 59%. 1H NMR (600 MHz, C6D6): δ 0.29 (s, 36H, SiMe3), 1.21 (d, 3 J HH = 6.9 Hz, 24H, iPr), 1.32 (d, 3 J HH = 6.8 Hz, 24H, iPr), 1.42 (s, 6H, Me), 3.47 (hept, 3 J HH = 6.8 Hz, 8H, iPr), 7.09–7.19 (m, 12H, Ar). 13C NMR (151 MHz, C6D6): δ 6.8 (SiMe3), 18.8 (Me), 24.9 (iPr), 25.4 (iPr), 28.1 (iPr), 123.8 (Ar), 124.1 (Ar), 142.9 (Ar), 146.9 (Ar), 174.9 (NCN). Anal. Calcd for the monomer with two cocrystallized molecules of hexane, C44H83N3Si2Ca: C, 70.43; H, 11.15. Found: C, 70.05; H, 10.97.

Synthesis of AdAm<sup>DIPP</sup>CaN­(SiMe<sub>3</sub>)<sub>2</sub>·THFRoute A

AdAmDIPPH (300 mg, 0.60 mmol) and KN­(SiMe3)2 (240 mg, 1.20 mmol) were dissolved in 20 mL of THF and stirred at room temperature for 1 h. CaI2 (212 mg, 0.72 mmol) was added under N2, and the slurry was stirred at 70 °C under reflux for 2 days. THF was removed under vacuum and the product extracted with 10 mL of hexane. The hexane phase was separated from the precipitate by centrifugation and concentrated to a third of the initial volume. Slow cooling to −20 °C gave precipitation of a white microcrystalline product which was washed with cold pentane (1 mL) and dried under vacuum. Yield: 339 mg, 73%.

Route B

AdAmDIPPH (300 mg, 0.60 mmol) was dissolved in toluene (10 mL) and added very slowly to Ca­[N­(SiMe3)2]2·2THF (270 mg, 0.53 mmol) under N2 and fast stirring through a septum. The reaction mixture was placed at 100 °C for 2 days, after which the solvent was removed and the product extracted with hexane (20 mL). The solution was then centrifuged, concentered to a fourth of the initial volume, and cooled to −20 °C very slowly. (Et2O)2 (100 mg, 144 μmol) was dissolved in hexane (5 mL) and cooled to −30 °C. PhSiH3 (19.5 μL, 158.4 μmol) was added and, with standing in the cooling bath, the reaction mixture was slowly warmed to room temperature without stirring for 1 day. Already after a few hours small needle-shaped crystals started to form in solution, and after 1 day no further crystals formed. The colorless crystals were then separated from the mother liquor, washed three times with ice-cold pentane, (0.5 mL) and collected. Yield: 53.3 mg, 58 μmol, 80%. 1H NMR (600 MHz, C6D6): δ 1.16 (d, 3 J HH = 6.9 Hz, 12H, iPr), 1.23 (d, 3 J HH = 6.8 Hz, 12H, iPr), 1.33 (d, 3 J HH = 6.8 Hz, 12H, iPr), 1.36 (d, 3 J HH = 6.8 Hz, 12H, iPr) 1.48 (s, 18H, tBu backbone), 3.09 (s, 2H, CaH), 3.18 (hept, 3 J HH = 6.8 Hz, 4H, iPr), 3.36 (hept, 3 J HH = 6.3 Hz, 4H, iPr), 6.52 (t, 3 J HH = 7.6 Hz, 2H, ArCH para), 7.14–7.05 (m, 10H, Ar). 13C NMR (75 MHz, C6D6; due to low solubility, only 15 of the 17 expected signals were detected): δ 20.70 (iPr), 22.75 (iPr), 24.04 (iPr), 27.14 (iPr), 27.91 (iPr), 29.01 (iPr), 31.63 (C­(CH3)3), 41.89 (C(CH3)3), 120.04 (Ar), 123.43 (Ar), 123.98 (Ar), 125.26 (Ar), 143.13 (Ar), 144.48 (Ar), 170.0 (NCN Amidinate). Synthesis of (AdAm<sup>DIPP</sup>CaH)<sub>2</sub>

AdAmDIPPCaN­(SiMe3)2 (100 mg, 143 μmol) was dissolved in hexane (5 mL), and then PhSiH3 was added (19,4 μL, 1.1 equiv). Keeping the solution at room temperature without stirring for 2 days gave needlelike colorless crystals. The crystals were separated from the mother liquor and washed twice with ice cold pentane (5 mL each) and dried under vacuum. Yield: 54 mg, 69%. 1H NMR (400 MHz, C6D6): δ 1.19 (d, 3 J HH = 6.9 Hz, 12H, iPr), 1.25 (d, 3 J HH = 6.7 Hz, 12H, iPr), 1.36 (d, 3 J HH = 6.6 Hz, 12H, iPr), 1.42 (d, 3 J HH = 6.7 Hz, 12H, iPr), 1.66 (d, 3 J HH = 11.9 Hz, 6H, Ad), 1.79 (d, 3 J HH = 11.3 Hz, 6H, Ad), 1.99 (s, br, 6H), 2.44–2.31 (m, 12H, Ad), 3.07 (s, 2H, Ca–H), 3.22 (hept, 3 J HH = 6.6 Hz, 4H, Ar), 3.39 (hept, 3 J HH = 6.9 Hz, 4H, iPr), 6.55 (t, 3 J HH = 7.6 Hz, 2H, Ar), 7.14–6.99 (m, 10H, Ar). 13C NMR (151 MHz, C6D6): δ 20.76 (iPr), 24.11 iPr), 24.27 (Ad), 27.27 (iPr), 27.86 (iPr), 29.00 (iPr), 29.72 (Ad), 37.43 (Ad), 42.54 (Ad), 44.70 (C-Ad), 119.96 (Ar), 123.31 (Ar), 124.00 (Ar), 125.24 (Ar), 142.97 (Ar), 144.37 (Ar), 144.59 (Ar), 161.00 (Ar), 170.03 (NCN). Anal. Calcd for C70H100Ca2N4: C, 78.01; H, 9.35; N, 5.20. Found: C, 77.75; H, 9.16; N, 5.11.

Synthesis of (tBuAm<sup>DIPP</sup>CaH)<sub>3</sub>·2Et<sub>2</sub>O

An NMR tube was charged with needlelike crystals of (tBuAmDIPPCaH)2 (35 mg, 38 μmol) and suspended in Et2O (600 μL) and left at 40 °C for 7 days. After a few hours, large colorless blocks started to appear among the small needle-shaped crystals. After 7 days a batch of uniform block-shaped crystals could be observed. Et2O was removed, and the crystals were washed twice with cold pentane (600 μL at −30 °C each) and then measured. Yield: 37.2 mg, 96%. NMR measurement of the product in THF-d 8 gave immediate decomposition into the homoleptic species (tBuAmDIPP)2Ca and CaH2 (see the Supporting Information). The product is extremely insoluble in aromatic solvents. Heating a sample in C6D6 in order to dissolve the crystals gave conversion to the dimer (tBuAmDIPPCaH)2, free Et2O, and traces of homoleptic (tBuAmDIPP)2Ca (see the Supporting Information). Anal. Calcd for (tBuAmDIPPCaH)3·2Et2O, C95H152Ca3N6O2: C, 74.55; H, 10.01. Found: C, 74.96; H, 9.76. Although the C value is outside the range viewed as establishing analytical purity, it matches better with a product in which one of the Et2O ligands is missing as a consequence of workup (drying under high vacuum). (tBuAmDIPPCaH)3·Et2O C91H142Ca3N6O: C, 75.05; H, 9.83. IR (pure, cm–1): ν̃̃ 2957 (s), 2901 (s), 2868 (s), 2845 (s), 2140 (w), 1474 (s), 1427 (s), 1417 (s), 1398 (s), 1382 (s), 1355 (m), 1306 (m), 1259 (m), 1228 (s), 1185 (s), 1076 (w), 1040 (s), 929 (s), 896 (s), 844 (m), 799 (s), 757 (s), 726 (m), 699 (m), 536 (m).

Synthesis of (AdAm<sup>DIPP</sup>CaH)<sub>3</sub>·2THF

AdAmDIPPCaN­(SiMe3)2·(THF) (35 mg, 45.4 μmol) was dissolved in pentane (1 mL) in an NMR tube, and the solution was cooled to −30 °C. PhSiH3 (6.2 μL, 50 μmol) was added at −30 °C. While the tube was kept in the cooling bath, the temperature was raised slowly to room temperature. A uniform batch of colorless blocklike crystals suitable for X-ray diffraction grew over the time of 1 week. The crystals were separated from the mother liquor and washed twice with cold pentane (500 μL at −30 °C each) to be measured. Yield: 23 mg, 86%. Dissolving the complex in C6D6 gave immediate decomposition into homoleptic species and gave a precipitate of presumably CaH2. Anal. Calcd for (AdAmDIPPCaH)3·2THF, C113H166Ca3N6O2: C, 77.08; H, 9.50. Found: C, 77.50; H, 9.42. The elemental analysis matches better with for a product in which one molecule of THF is lost during workup. (AdAmDIPPCaH)3·THF, C109H158Ca3N6O: C, 77.53; H, 9.43. IR (pure, cm–1): ν̃̃ 3051 (w), 2957 (s), 2902 (s), 2137 (w), 1455 (m), 1429 (s), 1394 (s), 1312 (m), 1252 (m), 1234 (m), 1137 (m), 1109 (w), 1056 (m), 1026 (m), 932 (m), 875 (m), 821 (m), 755 (m), 697 (m), 659 (w), 589 (w).

Synthesis of Ca[N(SiMe3)2]2⋅2Et2O

CaI2 (1.50 g, 5.10 mmol) and KN(SiMe3)2 (2.30 g, 11.53 mmol) were suspended in 50 mL of Et2O and stirred under reflux conditions for 5 days. The solvent was then removed under vacuum, and the product was extracted with 100 mL of hexane. Concentration to one-fifth of the initial volume and cooling to 4 °C resulted in the formation of large colorless blocks which were washed twice with ice-cold pentane (10 mL) and dried under vacuum. Further cooling of the isolated mother liquor to -20 °C afforded a new batch of crystals, which were worked up as already described. Yield of the combined batches: 2.54 g, 98%. 1H NMR (400 MHz, C6D6): δ 0.29 (s, 36H, Me3Si), 0.97 (t, 3 J HH = 7.0 Hz, 12H, Et2O), 3.33 (q, 3 J HH = 7.0 Hz, 8H, Et2O). 13C NMR (101 MHz, C6D6): δ 5.8 (Me3Si), 14.4 (Et2O), 65.3 (Et2O). Anal. Calcd for C20H56N2O2Si4Ca: C, 47.18; H, 11.09; N, 5.50. Found: C, 46.90; H, 11.03; N, 5.31.

Synthesis of AdAmDIPPCaN(SiMe3)2 

The complex can be obtained following two different synthetic procedures, route A and B (see b).

Route A

AdAmDIPPH (300 mg, 0.60 mmol) and KN(SiMe3)2 (240 mg, 1.20 mmol) were dissolved in 20 mL of Et2O and stirred at room temperature for 1 h. CaI2 (177 mg, 0.60 mmol) was added under N2, and the slurry was stirred at 40 °C under reflux conditions for 3 days. Et2O was removed under vacuum, and the product was extracted with 20 mL of hexane. The hexane phase was collected after centrifugation and concentrated to half of its initial volume. Slow cooling to -20 °C resulted in the precipitation of a white powdery product which was washed with cold pentane (5 mL) and dried under vacuum. Yield: 57 mg, 14%.

Synthesis of tBuAmDIPPCaN(SiMe3)2⋅Et2O

Route A

 tBuAmDIPPH (500 mg, 1.19 mmol) and KN(SiMe3)2 (474 mg, 2.38 mmol) were dissolved in 20 mL of Et2O and stirred for 1 h at room temperature. Then CaI2 (384 mg, 1.19 mmol) was added under N2, and the resulting slurry was stirred for 1 day at 40 °C under reflux conditions. The solvent was removed under vacuum, and 20 mL of hexane was added to extract the product. The hexane phase was centrifuged, collected, and concentrated to half of the initial volume and then cooled to -20 °C for 12 h. The product was isolated as colorless blocks which were washed with cold pentane (2 mL) and dried under vacuum. Yield: 721 mg, 87%.

Route B

 tBuAmDIPPH (500 mg, 1.19 mmol) was dissolved in 20 mL of Et2O and added slowly and dropwise to Ca[N(SiMe3)2]2⋅2Et2O (606 mg, 1.19 mmol) under N2 through a septum. The clear solution was stirred for 1 day at room temperature, and then Et2O was removed under vacuum. A 20 mL portion of hexane was added to extract the product. After centrifugation, the collected mother liquor was concentrated to half of its initial volume and slow cooling to -20 °C gave colorless crystals which were washed with cold pentane (2 mL) and dried under vacuum. Yield: 738 mg, 89%. 1H NMR (600 MHz, benzene-d 6): δ 0.04 (s, 18H, Me3Si), 0.96 (t, 3 J HH = 7.0 Hz, 6H, Et2O), 1.00 (s, br, 9H, tBu), 1.30 (d, 3 J HH = 6.4 Hz, 12H, iPr), 1.37 (d, 3 J HH = 6.4 Hz, 12H, iPr), 3.48 (hept, 4H, iPr), 3.57 (q, 3 J HH = 7.0 Hz, 4H, Et2O), 6.96-7.15 (m, 6H, Ar). 13C NMR (151 MHz, C6D6): δ 5.3 (Me3Si), 14.1 (Et2O), 23.1 (iPr), 26.5 (iPr), 28.8 (iPr), 31.4 (C(CH3)3), 45.6 (C(CH3)3), 65.0 (Et2O), 122.8 (Ar), 123.5 (Ar), 140.6 (Ar), 146.7 (Ar), 178.2 (NCN). Anal. Calcd for C39H71N3OSi2Ca: C, 67.47; H, 10.31; N, 6.05. Found: C, 67.21; H, 10.28; N, 5.90.

Synthesis of NpAmDIPPCaN(SiMe3)2⋅Et2O

Route A

NpAmDIPPH (400 mg, 0.92 mmol) and KN(SiMe3)2 (385 mg, 1.93 mmol) were dissolved in 20 mL of Et2O and stirred at room temperature for 1 h. Then CaI2 (297 mg, 1.01 mmol) was added under N2, and the slurry was stirred at 40 °C under reflux conditions for 1 day. Et2O was removed under vacuum and the product extracted with 20 mL of hexane. After centrifugation of the hexane phase, concentration to a fifth of the initial volume, and cooling to -20 °C, colorless crystals were obtained. The crystals were washed with ice-cold pentane (3 mL) and dried under vacuum. Yield: 617 mg, 94%.

Route B

NpAmDIPPH (400 mg, 0.92 mmol) was dissolved in 20 mL of Et2O and added slowly and dropwise to Ca[N(SiMe3)2]2⋅2Et2O (468 mg, 0.92 mmol) under N2 through a septum. The clear solution was stirred for 1 day at room temperature, after which Et2O was removed under vacuum. A 20 mL portion of hexane was added to extract the product. After centrifugation of the hexane phase, concentration to one-fourth of the initial volume, and slow cooling to -20 °C, large colorless blocks of the product were obtained which were washed with ice-cold pentane (2 mL) and dried under vacuum. Yield: 526 mg, 80%. 1H NMR (400 MHz, C6D6): δ 0.07 (s, 18H, Me3Si), 0.55 (s, 9H, MeNp), 1.02 (t, 3 J HH = 7.0 Hz, 6H; Et2O), 1.26 (d, 3 J HH = 6.7 Hz, 12H, iPr), 1.38 (d, 3 J HH = 6.8 Hz, 12H, iPr), 2.45 (s, 2H, CH2-Np), 3.38 (q, 3 J HH = 6.6 Hz, 4H, Et2O), 3.47 (hept, 3 J HH = 6.8 Hz, 4H, iPr), 6.94-7.15 (m, 6H, Ar). 13C NMR (101 MHz, C6D6): δ 5.6 (Me3Si), 14.9 (Et2O), 23.2 (Me-Np), 26.9 (iPr), 28.6 (iPr), 31.4 (iPr), 31.6 (CH2-Np), 39.6 (Np), 65.7 (Et2O), 123.5 (Ar), 123.8 (Ar), 141.9 (Ar), 145.9 (Ar), 177.00 (NCN). Anal. Calcd for C40H73N3OSi2Ca: C, 67.83; H, 10.39; N, 5.93. Found: C, 67.52; H, 10.42; N, 5.77.

Synthesis of [p-TolAmDIPPCaN(SiMe3)2]2 

Route A

 p-TolAmDIPPH (200 mg, 0.44 mmol) and KN(SiMe3)2 (175 mg, 0.88 mmol) were dissolved in 20 mL of Et2O and stirred at room temperature for 1 h. Then CaI2 (129 mg, 0.44 mmol) was added under N2, and the slurry was stirred at 40 °C under reflux conditions for 1 day. Et2O was removed under vacuum and the product extracted with 20 mL of 9/1 pentane/Et2O mixture. The solution of the raw product was concentrated to one-third of its initial volume and layered with pentane. Slow cooling to -20 °C afforded a microcrystalline product which was washed with cold pentane and dried under vacuum. Suitable crystals for X-ray spectroscopy could be obtained on recrystallizing the product from toluene. Yield: 258 mg, 91%.

Route B

 p-TolAmDIPPH (200 mg, 0.44 mmol) was dissolved in 5 mL of Et2O and added slowly and dropwise to Ca[N(SiMe3)2]2⋅2Et2O (224 mg, 0.44 mmol) under N2 through a septum. The clear solution was stirred for 1 day at room temperature, after which Et2O was removed under vacuum. A 10 mL portion of toluene was added to extract the product, and after centrifugation of the hexane phase and further concentration to one-fourth of the initial volume, the solution was slowly cooled to -20 °C. Colorless blocks of the product grew overnight which were washed twice with ice-cold pentane (2 mL) and dried under vacuum. Route A

Route A gave the calcate complex (MeAmDIPP)[N(SiMe3)2]2CaK (see the Supporting Information).

MeAmDIPPH (200 mg, 0.53 mmol) was dissolved in benzene (10 mL) and added very slowly to Ca[N(SiMe3)2]2⋅2Et2O (270 mg, 0.53 mmol) under N2 with fast stirring through a septum. The reaction mixture was kept at room temperature for 2 h, after which the clear solution was concentrated to approximately 1 mL. Although the C value is outside the range viewed as establishing analytical purity, it matches better with a product in which one of the Et2O ligands is missing as a consequence of workup (drying under high vacuum). IR (pure, cm-1): ν̃̃ 2957 (s), 2901 (s), 2868 (s), 2845 (s), 2140 (w), 1474 (s), 1427 (s), 1417 (s), 1398 (s), 1382 (s), 1355 (m), 1306 (m), 1259 (m), 1228 (s), 1185 (s), 1076 (w), 1040 (s), 929 (s), 896 (s), 844 (m), 799 (s), 757 (s), 726 (m), 699 (m), 536 (m).

Synthesis of (AdAmDIPPCaH)3⋅2THF

AdAmDIPPCaN(SiMe3)2⋅(THF) (35 mg, 45.4 μmol) was dissolved in pentane (1 mL) in an NMR tube, and the solution was cooled to -30 °C. PhSiH3 (6.2 μL, 50 μmol) was added at -30 °C. While the tube was kept in the cooling bath, the temperature was raised slowly to room temperature. A uniform batch of colorless blocklike crystals suitable for X-ray diffraction grew over the time of 1 week. The crystals were separated from the mother liquor and washed twice with cold pentane (500 μL at -30 °C each) to be measured. Yield: 23 mg, 86%. Dissolving the complex in C6D6 gave immediate decomposition into homoleptic species and gave a precipitate of presumably CaH2. Anal. Calcd for (AdAmDIPPCaH)3⋅2THF, C113H166Ca3N6O2: C, 77.08; H, 9.50. Found: C, 77.50; H, 9.42. The elemental analysis matches better with for a product in which one molecule of THF is lost during workup. (AdAmDIPPCaH)3⋅THF, C109H158Ca3N6O: C, 77.53; H, 9.43. IR (pure, cm-1): ν̃̃ 3051 (w), 2957 (s), 2902 (s), 2137 (w), 1455 (m), 1429 (s), 1394 (s), 1312 (m), 1252 (m), 1234 (m), 1137 (m), 1109 (w), 1056 (m), 1026 (m), 932 (m), 875 (m), 821 (m), 755 (m), 697 (m), 659 (w), 589 (w).
